<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS</FONT></B>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">For the Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2002,
2001 and 2000</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Background and
Organization</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Description of Business.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">Fidelity National Information
Solutions, Inc. (&#147;FNIS&#148; or &#147;the Company&#148;)
provides data, technology solutions and services needed by
lenders and real estate professionals. FNIS is the only national
provider whose offerings span the entire home purchase and
ownership life cycle, from contact through closing, refinancing
and resale. The products and services the Company provides
enable its customers to use information to improve their
business decision-making processes and to effectively manage
existing and prospective customer relationships. The
Company&#146;s product and service offerings include a full
spectrum of technology solutions, electronic partner networks,
loan origination systems, real estate data and tax services,
credit reporting services, flood compliance services, and
automated valuation and appraisal services. The Company is also
a data and service provider to the Multiple Listing Service
(&#147;MLS&#148;) systems industry. Its data, web services, MLS
systems, and production and management software serve more than
50% of the nation&#146;s Realtors&#174;. The Company&#146;s
common stock is traded on the NASDAQ National Market under the
symbol &#147;FNIS&#148;.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company is a majority-owned subsidiary of
Fidelity National Financial, Inc. (NYSE: FNF&nbsp;&#151;
&#147;Fidelity&#148;). As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, Fidelity
owned approximately 66% of the Company&#146;s outstanding common
stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Fidelity is the nation&#146;s largest title
insurance and diversified real estate-related services company.
Fidelity&#146;s title insurance underwriters&nbsp;&#151;
Fidelity National Title, Chicago Title, Ticor Title, Security
Union Title and Alamo Title&nbsp;&#151; together issue
approximately 29&nbsp;percent of all title insurance policies
issued nationally in 2001. The Company provides title insurance
in 49 states, the District of Columbia, Guam, Puerto Rico, and
the U.S. Virgin Islands and in Canada and Mexico.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Formation of the Company.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">The Company was formerly Vista
Information Solutions, Inc. (&#147;Vista&#148;), a publicly
traded company and a provider of software solutions to the real
estate industry, including hosting MLS applications.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On March&nbsp;20, 2000, Fidelity consummated a
merger with Chicago Title Corporation, as a result of which
Fidelity acquired Chicago Title and Trust Company (&#147;Chicago
Title&#148;). Subsequent to the merger, Fidelity combined its
flood services (&#147;Fidelity Flood&#148;) and credit services
(&#147;Fidelity Credit&#148;) with the flood services
(&#147;Chicago Flood&#148;) and credit services (&#147;Chicago
Credit&#148;) of Chicago Title. The merged flood services
business (&#147;Fidelity National Flood, Inc.&#148; or
&#147;Flood&#148;) and the merged credit services business
(&#147;Fidelity National Credit Services, Inc.&#148; or
&#147;Credit&#148;) became wholly-owned subsidiaries of Chicago
Title. On January&nbsp;3, 2001, Fidelity also acquired 100% of
the outstanding stock of International Data Management
Corporation (&#147;IDM&#148;).
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On August&nbsp;1, 2001, the Company, pursuant to
an Agreement and Plan of Reorganization and Merger dated
April&nbsp;12, 2001, acquired IDM from Fidelity; and Market
Intelligence (&#147;MI&#148;), Flood and Credit (collectively,
the &#147;Chicago Subsidiaries&#148;) from Chicago Title, by
merging these four subsidiaries with and into four
previously-formed merger subsidiaries of the Company in
simultaneous reverse triangular mergers (collectively, the
&#147;Mergers&#148;). Concurrent with the Mergers, Fidelity
transferred 80% of the issued and outstanding stock of Fidelity
National Tax Service, Inc. (&#147;Tax,&#148; and together with
IDM, the &#147;Fidelity Subsidiaries&#148;) to the Company (the
&#147;Share Exchange&#148;). As a result of the Mergers and the
Share Exchange, MI, Credit, Flood and IDM became wholly-owned
subsidiaries of the Company, and Tax became a majority-owned
subsidiary of the Company.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In consideration for the Mergers and the Share
Exchange, the Company transferred to Chicago Title and Fidelity
11,703,801 shares and 5,507,671 shares of the Company&#146;s
common stock, respectively. Collectively, these shares of common
stock then constituted approximately 77% of the outstanding
capital stock of the Company. This transaction had the effect of
a reverse merger, following which the Company became a
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">41
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">majority-owned subsidiary of Fidelity. As a
result, the accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements
issued prior to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 only
reflect the financial position, results of operations and cash
flows of the Fidelity Subsidiaries and the Chicago Subsidiaries
prior to the Mergers, as the Fidelity Subsidiaries and the
Chicago Subsidiaries were treated as the acquirer for accounting
purposes. Vista&#146;s results were included in the results of
operations since the closing of the business combination on
August&nbsp;1, 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The total purchase price of $34.8&nbsp;million
was allocated to the tangible assets acquired, goodwill, and
liabilities assumed, at fair value, in the amounts of
$45.5&nbsp;million, $29.7&nbsp;million and $40.4&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of
Significant Accounting Policies</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following describes the significant
accounting policies followed by the Company in preparing the
accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Principles of
Consolidation and Basis of Presentation</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The accompanying Consolidated Financial
Statements include the accounts of the Company and its
wholly-owned subsidiaries. All material inter-company
transactions and balances have been eliminated.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As a result of the merger with the Fidelity
Subsidiaries and the Chicago Subsidiaries on August&nbsp;1, 2001
(see Note&nbsp;1), the Consolidated Financial Statements of the
Company prior to the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 reflect
the financial position, results of operations and cash flows of
the Fidelity and Chicago Subsidiaries prior to the merger, as
the Fidelity Subsidiaries and Chicago Subsidiaries were treated
as the acquirer for accounting purposes. The Company&#146;s
financial results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001
include the operations of the Fidelity Subsidiaries and Chicago
Subsidiaries for the full year of 2001 and Vista&#146;s
operations for the period from August&nbsp;1, 2001, the
acquisition date, through December&nbsp;31, 2001. The financial
results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 include the
results of Fidelity Flood, Fidelity Credit and Tax
(collectively, the &#147;Fidelity Companies&#148;) for the full
year, and the results of the MI, Chicago Flood and Chicago
Credit from and after March 20, 2000, the date when Chicago
Title was acquired by Fidelity.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As described in Note 3, the Company acquired
Micro General Corporation (&#147;MGEN&#148;) on July&nbsp;9,
2002, including a 51.6% majority ownership acquired from its
parent company, Fidelity. The acquisition of Fidelity&#146;s
majority interest in MGEN was accounted for in a manner similar
to a pooling-of-interests because the Company and MGEN were
entities under common control of Fidelity. As required by
generally accepted accounting principles in the U.S., the
accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements have been
prepared to give retroactive effect to the merger and
accordingly, all amounts contained herein have been prepared as
if the transaction took place on the first day of the years
presented.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Certain reclassifications have been made in the
2001 and 2000 Consolidated Financial Statements to conform to
the classifications used in 2002. These include those
adjustments and reclassification necessary to reflect the merger
of MGEN in a manner similar to a pooling-of-interests.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Management
Estimates</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The preparation of these Consolidated Financial
Statements in conformity with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States of America requires management to
make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts
of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets
and liabilities at the date of the Consolidated Financial
Statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses
during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from
those estimates.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Cash and Cash
Equivalents</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The carrying value of cash and cash equivalents
at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001 approximates their fair value
due to the short-term nature of these items. Cash equivalents
consist of instruments with an original maturity of 90&nbsp;days
or less.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">42
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Investments</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Short-term investments, consisting primarily of
money market instruments with an original maturity of one year
or less, are carried at cost, which approximate their fair value.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Accounts
Receivable</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The carrying amounts reported in the balance
sheets for accounts receivable approximate their fair value.
Accounts receivable is reported net of allowance for doubtful
accounts representing management&#146;s estimate of those
balances that are uncollectible as of the balance sheet date.
The allowance for doubtful accounts was $5.9&nbsp;million and
$3.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001,
respectively.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Property, Equipment and
    Software</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Property and equipment are recorded at cost, less
accumulated depreciation and amortization. Depreciation and
amortization is computed primarily using the straight-line
method based on the estimated useful lives of the related
assets, which range from three to 25&nbsp;years. Leasehold
improvements are amortized on a straight-line basis over the
lesser of the term of the applicable lease or the estimated
useful lives of such assets.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Software Development Costs and Purchased
    Software</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Costs incurred in creating computer software to
be licensed or sold are charged to expense when incurred until
technological feasibility has been established. Technological
feasibility is established upon completion of a detail program
design or, in its absence, completion of a working model. Costs
incurred in developing software intended for internal use are
capitalized after the initial planning phase is completed.
Thereafter, certain software production costs are capitalized
and subsequently reported at the lower of amortized cost or net
realizable value. Software development costs are amortized based
on current and future revenue for each product with an annual
minimum equal to the straight-line amortization over the
remaining estimated economic life of the product. Estimated
economic life is generally three to ten years.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Software obtained through business acquisition to
be marketed and sold is recorded at fair value and amortized at
a rate that approximates its estimated future cash flow, which
is typically three to ten years.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Accumulated amortization for software development
costs and purchased software was $15.0&nbsp;million and
$12.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001,
respectively. The net book value of software development costs
and purchased software were $40.6&nbsp;million and
$13.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001,
respectively. The related amortization expense was
$2.6&nbsp;million, $0.8&nbsp;million and $0.8&nbsp;million for
2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company regularly assesses the recoverability
of the cost of its capitalized software development costs and
software obtained through acquisition based on an analysis of
the undiscounted cash flows generated by the underlying assets.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Goodwill and Other Intangible
    Assets</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Goodwill represents the excess of purchase price
over the fair value of assets acquired and the liabilities
assumed relating to acquisitions. Prior to 2002, goodwill was
amortized on a straight-line basis over five to 25&nbsp;years.
In January 2002, the Company adopted Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&nbsp;142,
&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&#148; and as a
result, has ceased to amortize goodwill. Instead, the Company
was required to perform a transitional impairment review of its
goodwill as of January&nbsp;1, 2002 and an annual impairment
review thereafter. The Company has evaluated the impact of the
adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 and determined that no impairment
charge was required upon adoption of this standard. Its
impairment test was performed through comparison of the fair
value of the reporting units with the carrying value of their
assets. The Company will perform an impairment review on an
annual basis or when events or circumstances indicate potential
impairment. An annual goodwill impairment review was performed
by the
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">43
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">Company on its reporting units as of September
30, 2002 and it was determined that each reporting unit had a
fair value in excess of its carrying value. Accordingly, no
goodwill impairment has been recorded.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As described in Note 8, other intangible assets
primarily include contract values, service contracts with
Fidelity, trademarks, customer relationships and certain other
assets, and are amortized over the expected periods of benefit
of the assets. Multiple Listing System (&#147;MLS&#148;)
contracts are amortized over a ten to 25&nbsp;year life on a
basis consistent with the expected renewal rate of the
underlying contracts. One trademark and a joint venture
agreement totaling $5.0&nbsp;million possess characteristics
associated with an indefinite life and accordingly, are not
being amortized. The other intangible assets are amortized over
a two to 20&nbsp;year life either on a straight-line basis or at
a rate that approximates its future expected cash flow.
Impairment of intangible assets is monitored on a continuing
basis, and is assessed based on the undiscounted cash flows
generated by the underlying assets.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Revenue Recognition</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company recognizes revenue from the sale of
data or services when evidence of the arrangement exists,
delivery has occurred, the sales price has been determined and
collectibility is deemed probable, generally in the month in
which the report is delivered or in which information is
transmitted to the customer, in accordance with Staff Accounting
Bulletin No.&nbsp;101, &#147;Revenue Recognition&#148;
(&#147;SAB&nbsp;101&#148;). The Flood and Tax units of the
Company provide various services including life-of-loan
monitoring services. Revenue is recognized based on the
estimated fair value of services being provided upfront and over
the life of the loan. The amount recognized upfront is
approximately 75% for flood and 50% for tax of the total revenue
received. The amounts deferred are recognized ratably over the
estimated average life of the loan portfolio, which is
determined based on the Company&#146;s historical experience.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Revenue from the sale of software is recognized
in the month in which the revenue recognition criteria of
Statement of Position No.&nbsp;97-2, &#147;Software Revenue
Recognition&#148; (&#147;SOP&nbsp;97-2&#148;) are met, generally
the month in which the software is shipped to the customer.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company follows SOP&nbsp;81-1,
&#147;Accounting for Performance of Construction-Type and
Certain Production-Type Contracts&#148; for software contracts
with significant customization. Revenue is recognized from
software contracts with customization using the percentage of
completion method of accounting whereby revenue is recognized
based on the stage of completion of individual contracts using
estimates of service days to total estimated service days.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">System solutions sold to customers may involve a
selection of the following elements: computer hardware (sold or
leased), internally developed software, telecommunications
services, information security, training and customer support.
These system solutions services have been accounted for under
the provisions of SOP&nbsp;97-2. Revenue recognition commences
at the point at which the Company has delivered to the customer
all elements essential to the functionality of the system
solutions. Accordingly, the Company defers and recognizes
revenue associated with these arrangements ratably over the
terms of the underlying agreements, commencing at contract
&#147;cutover.&#148; Cutover is generally defined as the point
at which the hardware is installed, software has been delivered,
training is completed, and the service is accessible to and
usable by the customer. Cash received prior to cutover is
deferred and recognized as revenue ratably over the life of the
contract. For certain sales, the Company provides 90 to
360&nbsp;days initial maintenance and support to the customer.
Costs relating to this initial support period are accrued at the
time of the sale.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Certain other elements of the agreements, such as
ongoing maintenance, involve separately stated monthly fees.
Revenues associated with such other elements are recognized over
the periods during which the services are performed, generally
on a monthly basis.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Hardware may be sold or leased to the
Company&#146;s system solutions customers. Such hardware is a
standard, non-customized equipment that can be used for other
information processing applications. Leases of
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">44
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">hardware are generally classified as
&#147;sales-type leases&#148; in accordance with the provisions
of SOP&nbsp;97-2 and SFAS No.&nbsp;13, &#147;Accounting for
Leases,&#148; and revenue is recognized upon delivery.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Revenues from providing management support and
consulting services are recognized as services are performed.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Income Taxes</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company recognizes deferred tax assets and
liabilities for temporary differences between the financial
reporting basis and the tax basis of the Company&#146;s assets
and liabilities and expected benefits of utilizing net operating
loss and credit carryforwards. Deferred tax assets and
liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to
apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary
differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The impact
on deferred taxes of changes in tax rates and laws, if any, are
applied to the years during which temporary differences are
expected to be settled and reflected in the financial statements
in the period enacted.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Earnings Per Share</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company presents &#147;basic&#148; earnings
per share, representing net earnings available to common
shareholders divided by the weighted average number of common
shares outstanding (excluding all common stock equivalents)
during the period, and &#147;diluted&#148; earnings per share,
representing the dilutive effect of all common stock
equivalents. The Company has granted certain options and
warrants which have been treated as common share equivalents for
the purpose of calculating diluted earnings per share.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Stock Options</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company accounts for stock-based employee
compensation arrangements in accordance with Accounting
Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;25 (&#147;APB
Opinion&nbsp;25&#148;), &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to
Employees,&#148; and related Interpretations, and complies with
the disclosure provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123, &#147;Accounting
for Stock-Based Compensation.&#148; Under APB Opinion&nbsp;25,
compensation expense is recognized over the vesting period based
on the difference, if any, on the date of grant between the
deemed fair value for accounting purposes of the Company&#146;s
stock and the exercise price. All options granted under the
Company&#146;s plans had an exercise price equal to the market
value of the underlying common stock at the date of grant;
therefore, no stock-based compensation cost is reflected in net
income for stock options issued to employees. The Company
accounts for stock-issued to non-employees in accordance with
the provision of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 and EITF&nbsp;96-18,
&#147;Accounting for Equity Instruments That Are Issued to Other
Than Employees for Acquiring, or in Conjunction with Selling,
Goods and Services.&#148;
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">SFAS No.&nbsp;123, &#147;Accounting for Stock
Based Compensation&#148; provides an alternative fair value
approach in valuing employee stock options. This approach
requires the use of the &#147;Black-Scholes&#148; option
valuation model, which was not developed for use in valuing
employee stock options. This valuation model was developed for
the purpose of estimating the fair value of traded options,
which do not have vesting restrictions and are fully
transferable. In addition, the option valuation models require
the input of highly subjective assumptions including the
expected stock price volatility. Because the Company&#146;s
stock options have characteristics significantly different from
those of traded options and because changes in the subjective
input assumptions can materially affect the value of an
estimate, in management&#146;s opinion, the existing models do
not necessarily provide a reliable single measure of the fair
value of its employee stock options.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Pro forma information regarding net earnings and
earnings per share is required by SFAS No.&nbsp;123, and has
been determined as if the Company had accounted for its employee
stock options under the fair value method of such statement. The
fair value for these options was estimated at the date of grant
using the
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">45
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As discussed in Note&nbsp;3, the Company incurred
$5.9&nbsp;million ($3.6&nbsp;million, net of tax) of non-cash
compensation charges in connection with the exchange of vested
and unvested MGEN options for FNIS options.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Concentration
of Credit Risk</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Financial instruments that potentially subject
the Company to concentration of credit risk consist primarily of
cash equivalents, short-term investments and trade receivables.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company places its cash equivalents and
short-term investments with high credit quality financial
institutions and, by policy, limits the amounts of credit
exposure with any one financial institution.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has certain concentration of credit
risk with respect to trade receivables and revenues. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, trade receivables from Fidelity
accounted for 33% and 29%, respectively, of the Company&#146;s
total trade receivables. In addition, the revenues from Fidelity
accounted for 31%, 37% and 43% of the Company&#146;s total
revenues for 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. Besides
Fidelity, concentration of credit risk with respect to trade
receivables and revenues is limited because a large number of
geographically diverse customers make up the Company&#146;s
customer base, thus spreading the credit risk. The Company
controls credit risk through credit approvals, credit limits and
monitoring procedures.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Segment
Information</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company reports segment information in
accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;131 &#147;Disclosures about
Segments of an Enterprise and Related Information.&#148; The
Company&#146;s operating segments are presented consistently
with the way that its management organizes and evaluates
financial information for making
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">46
</FONT>

Certain prior year segment information has been reclassified to
conform to the 2002 presentation (see Note&nbsp;16).
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Recent
Accounting Pronouncements</I></FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In July 2001, the Financial Accounting Standards
Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&nbsp;141,
&#147;Business Combinations&#148; and SFAS No.&nbsp;142,
&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets&#148;. SFAS
No.&nbsp;141 requires that all business combinations be
accounted for under the purchase method. The statement further
requires separate recognition of intangible assets that meet one
of two criteria. The statement applies to all business
combinations initiated after June&nbsp;30, 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">SFAS No.&nbsp;142 requires that an intangible
asset that is acquired shall be initially recognized and
measured based on its fair value. The statement also provides
that goodwill should not be amortized, but shall be tested for
impairment annually, or more frequently if circumstances
indicate potential impairment, through a comparison of fair
value to its carrying amount. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 is generally
effective for fiscal periods beginning after December&nbsp;15,
2001 and the amortization provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 are
effective for acquisitions subsequent to June&nbsp;30, 2001. The
Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;142 effective January&nbsp;1, 2002
(See Notes&nbsp;2 and 7).
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In October 2001, the FASB issued SFAS
No.&nbsp;144, &#147;Accounting for the Impairment of Long-Lived
Assets&#148; which addresses financial accounting and reporting
for the impairment or disposal of long-lived assets. While SFAS
No.&nbsp;144 supersedes SFAS No.&nbsp;121, &#147;Accounting for
the Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and for Long-Lived Assets to
be Disposed Of,&#148; it retains many of the fundamental
provisions of that statement. SFAS No.&nbsp;144 is effective for
fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2001. The
adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;144 did not have a material impact on
the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations and
cash flows.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In April 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;145,
&#147;Rescission of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;4, 44, and 64,
Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;13, and Technical
Corrections&#148; (&#147;SFAS&nbsp;145&#148;). SFAS&nbsp;145
rescinds SFAS&nbsp;4, which required all gains and losses from
extinguishment of debt to be aggregated and, if material,
classified as an extraordinary item, net of related income tax
effect. Upon adoption of SFAS&nbsp;145, the Company will be
required to apply the criteria in APB Opinion No.&nbsp;30,
Reporting the Results of Operations&nbsp;&#151; Reporting the
Effects of Disposal of a Segment of a Business, and
Extraordinary, Unusual and Infrequently Occurring Events and
Transactions (&#147;Opinion No.&nbsp;30&#148;), in determining
the classification of gains and losses resulting from the
extinguishment of debt. Additionally, SFAS&nbsp;145 amends
SFAS&nbsp;13 to require that certain lease modifications that
have economic effects similar to sale-leaseback transactions to
be accounted for in the same manner as sale-leaseback
transactions. SFAS&nbsp;145 will be effective for fiscal years
beginning after May&nbsp;15, 2002 with early adoption of the
provisions related to the rescission of SFAS&nbsp;4 encouraged.
Upon adoption, companies must reclassify prior period items that
do not meet the extraordinary item classification criteria in
Opinion No.&nbsp;30. The adoption of SFAS&nbsp;145 as of
December&nbsp;31, 2002 did not have a material impact on the
Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In June 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;146,
&#147;Accounting for Costs Associated with Exit and Disposal
Activities.&#148; SFAS&nbsp;146 nullifies Emerging Issues Task
Force (&#147;EITF&#148;) issue 94-3, Liability Recognition for
Certain Employee Termination Benefits and Other Costs to Exit an
Activity (including Certain Costs Incurred in a Restructuring).
Under EITF issue&nbsp;94-3, a liability for an exit cost is
recognized at the date of an entity&#146;s commitment to an exit
plan. Under SFAS&nbsp;146, the liabilities associated with an
exit or disposal activity will be measured at fair value and
recognized when the liability is incurred and meets the
definition of a liability in the FASB&#146;s conceptual
framework. This statement is effective for exit or disposal
activities initiated after December&nbsp;31, 2002. The Company
believes that the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;146 will not have a
material impact on its consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In November 2002, the FASB issued Interpretation
No.&nbsp;45, &#147;Guarantor&#146;s Accounting and Disclosure
Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect Guarantees of
Indebtedness to Others&#148; (&#147;FIN&nbsp;45&#148;), an
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">47
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">interpretation of FASB Statements Nos.&nbsp;5, 57
and 107 and a rescission of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;34.
FIN&nbsp;45 elaborates on the disclosures to be made by a
guarantor in its interim and annual financial statements about
its obligations under guarantees issued. FIN&nbsp;45 also
clarifies that a guarantor is required to recognize, at
inception of a guarantee, a liability for the fair value of the
obligation undertaken. The initial recognition and measurement
provisions of FIN 45 are applicable to guarantees issued or
modified after December&nbsp;31, 2002 and are not expected to
have an impact on the Company&#146;s financial position, results
of operations and cash flows.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In November 2002, the FASB&#146;s EITF issued
EITF 00-21 &#147;Revenue Arrangements with Multiple
Deliverables.&#148; EITF 00-21 addresses certain aspects of the
accounting by a vendor for arrangements under which it will
perform multiple revenue-generating activities. Specifically,
EITF 00-21 addresses how to determine whether an arrangement
involving multiple deliverables contains more than one unit of
accounting. In applying EITF 00-21, separate contracts with the
same entity or related parties that are entered into at or near
the same time are presumed to have been negotiated as a package
and should, therefore, be evaluated as a single arrangement in
considering whether there are one or more units of accounting.
That presumption may be overcome if there is sufficient evidence
to the contrary. EITF 00-21 also addresses how arrangement
consideration should be measured and allocated to the separate
units of accounting in the arrangement. The guidance in this
Issue is effective for revenue arrangements entered into in
fiscal periods beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2003.
Alternatively, companies may elect to report the change in
accounting as a cumulative-effect adjustment. Early application
of this consensus is permitted. The Company has not yet adopted
EITF 00-21 and is currently analyzing its impact on the
Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations and
cash flows.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In December 2002, the FASB issued SFAS
No.&nbsp;148, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
Compensation&nbsp;&#151; Transition and Disclosure&nbsp;&#151;
an amendment of SFAS No.&nbsp;123&#148;. This statement provides
alternative methods of transition for a voluntary change to the
fair value based method of accounting for stock-based employee
compensation. This statement also amends the disclosure
requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 and APB Opinion No.&nbsp;28,
&#147;Interim Financial Reporting,&#148; to require prominent
disclosures in both annual and interim financial statements
about the method of accounting for stock-based employee
compensation and the effect of the method used on reported
results. Certain of the disclosure modifications are required
for fiscal years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2002 and are
included in the Notes to these Consolidated Financial
Statements. The Company will implement SFAS No.&nbsp;148
effective January&nbsp;1, 2003 regarding disclosure requirements
for condensed financial statements for interim periods. The
Company&#146;s management has not yet determined whether they
will voluntarily change to the fair value based method of
accounting for stock-based employee compensation.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions/Dispositions</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following mergers and acquisitions occurred
during 2002 and 2001 and have been accounted for in the
accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements under the
purchase method of accounting for business combinations (except
for the acquisition of the majority interest of Micro General
Corporation as described below). The purchase price for the
business combinations were allocated based on the estimated fair
value of acquired assets and liabilities. The Company has yet to
obtain additional information related to the valuation of
certain assets and liabilities. However, the Company does not
believe the difference between the recorded book value and the
fair value ultimately assigned will be material.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Micro General Corporation Acquisition.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On April&nbsp;29, 2002, the Company
announced a tender offer for all of the outstanding shares of
Micro General Corporation (&#147;MGEN&#148;), a majority-owned
subsidiary of Fidelity whereby each share of MGEN common stock
would be exchanged for shares of the Company&#146;s common
stock. The Company closed this tender offer on July&nbsp;9, 2002
and received over 90% of the outstanding MGEN shares in response
to this offer. Also on July&nbsp;9, 2002, the Company acquired
the remaining outstanding stock of MGEN through a short-form
merger. As a result of the tender offer and subsequent
short-form merger MGEN became a wholly-owned subsidiary of the
Company. The tender offer
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">48
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">and merger were based on a fixed exchange ratio
of .696 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock for each share
of MGEN common stock. As a result, the Company issued 12,895,721
new shares of its common stock to acquire MGEN.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">MGEN is a provider of production and workflow
software systems to the title and real estate industries. The
acquisition is expected to integrate MGEN&#146;s production and
workflow software solutions into the Company&#146;s existing
solutions business segment in order to better position the
Company to execute its strategy. The Company also expects to
reduce its information technology costs through economies of
scale.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Prior to the merger, Fidelity held a controlling
interest in both MGEN and the Company. The acquisition of the
non-controlling equity interest of MGEN (48.4%) was accounted
for under the purchase method of accounting in accordance with
SFAS No.&nbsp;141, &#147;Business Combinations.&#148; Under the
purchase method of accounting, assets acquired and liabilities
assumed are recorded at their fair values. Goodwill is created
to the extent that the merger consideration including certain
acquisition and closing costs exceeds the fair value of the net
assets acquired. The total number of shares issued in acquiring
the minority interest in MGEN was 6,243,223, valued at
$149.3&nbsp;million, based upon the Company&#146;s average
closing price of $23.91 per share on the NASDAQ National Market
for the five day period beginning two days prior through two
days subsequent to April&nbsp;29, 2002, the last trading day
before the public announcement of this offer. The total purchase
price of $153.2&nbsp;million includes the fair value of warrants
of $3.3&nbsp;million and transaction costs.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following table summarizes the estimated fair
value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed at the date
of acquisition (in thousands):

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Of the $11.3&nbsp;million of acquired intangible
assets, $9.5&nbsp;million was assigned to contracts with
Fidelity in connection with maintaining, servicing and
developing Fidelity&#146;s software solutions. The related
useful life of the assets range from 30&nbsp;months to
20&nbsp;years (see Note&nbsp;8). The remaining $1.8&nbsp;million
was assigned to a maintenance and service contract for SoftPro,
a software application used in the real estate settlement
process, with an estimated useful life of 17&nbsp;years.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The goodwill of $128.0&nbsp;million is not
expected to be deductible for tax purposes.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The acquisition of Fidelity&#146;s interest in
MGEN (51.6%) is not considered a business combination because
the Company and MGEN were entities under common control of
Fidelity. As required by generally accepted accounting
principles, the Company, therefore, recorded this transaction in
a manner similar to the pooling-of-interests method of
accounting. Accordingly, all amounts contained herein have been
prepared as if the transaction took place on the first day of
the periods presented. Below is a reconciliation of income
statement data previously reported by the Company to the
combined amounts currently presented in the
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In connection with this transaction, the Company
issued 1,008,896&nbsp;options with an average exercise price of
$14.67 and 449,790 warrants with an average exercise price of
$6.68 in exchange for the outstanding MGEN options and warrants.
In accordance with Emerging Issues Task Force (&#147;EITF&#148;)
00-23, &#147;Issues Related to the Accounting for Stock
Compensation under APB Opinion No.&nbsp;25 and FASB
Interpretation No.&nbsp;44&#148;, the exchange of vested and
unvested stock options resulted in the Company recording
non-cash stock compensation charges of $5.9&nbsp;million for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. In connection with the
unvested options the Company also recorded an unearned
compensation cost, which is expensed over the vesting period of
the options. The balance remaining at December&nbsp;31, 2002 was
$1.6&nbsp;million. In 2002, the Company also expensed
transaction costs for legal, accounting, appraisal and financial
advisory services of $1.1&nbsp;million related to this
transaction.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Risco, Inc.</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> On
August&nbsp;2, 2001, the Company acquired 100% of the
outstanding common shares of Risco, Inc. (&#147;Risco&#148;)
from Fidelity. The results of Risco&#146;s operations have been
included in the Consolidated Financial Statements since that
date. Risco is a multiple listing service vendor. In connection
with this acquisition, the Company issued 1,614,286 of its
common stock at $7.34 per share. The total purchase price was
$11.9&nbsp;million and the Company recorded goodwill of
$3.4&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Reez.com.</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> On
August&nbsp;2, 2001, the Company purchased the assets and
liabilities of Reez.com (&#147;Reez&#148;) from Fidelity. The
results of Reez&#146;s operations have been included in the
Consolidated Financial Statements since that date. Reez&#146;s
software provides the realtor, consumer and settlement service
provider with an on-line platform to schedule, track and close
real estate transactions. As a result of this acquisition, the
Company issued 136,971 of its common stock at $7.34 per share.
The total purchase price was $1.0&nbsp;million and the goodwill
in connection with the acquisition was immaterial.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">SoftPro Corporation.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On August&nbsp;20, 2001, MGEN acquired
SoftPro Corporation (&#147;SoftPro&#148;), a provider of real
estate closing and title insurance automation software for the
independent title agent marketplace. The purchase price was
$1.75&nbsp;million in cash and 336,034&nbsp;shares of
MGEN&#146;s common stock valued at $3.9&nbsp;million.
SoftPro&#146;s results of operations were included in the
Company&#146;s results of operations
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">50
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">since the acquisition date as a result of the
pooling-of-interests accounting treatment of the MGEN
transaction.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Tax Services.</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> On
October&nbsp;10, 2001, the Company purchased the residual 20%
minority interest in Tax Services for $5.4&nbsp;million in cash
that resulted in goodwill of $4.5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">RealEC Technologies.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">In November 2001, MGEN issued
153,893&nbsp;shares of MGEN&#146;s common stock, at $10.24 per
share, to two shareholders of RealEC Technologies
(&#147;RealEC&#148;) in exchange for 100% of the common stock of
RealEC. RealEC provides a standardized electronic platform which
lenders and realtors can utilize to order and receive products
and services from multiple vendors such as credit, flood,
appraisal, title and closing. As RealEC has outstanding
convertible preferred stock held by outside parties in an amount
of $7.1&nbsp;million, MGEN owns 56% of RealEC on an as-if
converted basis assuming conversion of all convertible preferred
stock. RealEC&#146;s results were consolidated with the
Company&#146;s results effective since the acquisition date as a
result of the pooling-of-interests accounting treatment of the
MGEN transaction.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">XMLS Web Division of HomeSeekers.com.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On December&nbsp;3, 2001, the Company
purchased all the assets of HomeSeekers.com&#146;s XMLS Web
division in exchange for $3.2&nbsp;million in cash. As a result
of this acquisition, the Company recorded goodwill of
$1.0&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">ISDI.Net.</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> On
January&nbsp;2, 2002, the Company acquired ISDI.NET, LLC
(&#147;ISDI&#148;), a technology, systems integration and
consulting firm, in exchange for 275,000&nbsp;shares of the
Company&#146;s common stock and $1.1&nbsp;million in cash. Prior
to the acquisition, the Company advanced to ISDI
$1.0&nbsp;million, which was included in Other Assets as of
December&nbsp;31, 2001. As a result of this acquisition, the
Company recorded goodwill of $1.3&nbsp;million. Under the
agreement, the owner of ISDI had the right to receive additional
consideration from the Company based on ISDI&#146;s earnings. In
2002, the Company issued approximately 60,000&nbsp;shares of
common stock in exchange for such right.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Hansen Quality Loan Services, LLC.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On May&nbsp;28, 2002 the Company
acquired a 55% interest in Hansen Quality Loan Services, LLC
(&#147;Hansen&#148;), a provider of collateral risk assessment
and valuation services for real estate mortgage financing, for
$4.1&nbsp;million in cash and a convertible note. The note is in
the amount of $4.1&nbsp;million, bears interest at 4.5%, matures
in May 2005, and was convertible into shares of the
Company&#146;s stock at $28.00 per share. In December 2002 the
conversion feature of the note was eliminated by mutual consent
of the parties to the note. The total purchase price was
$8.3&nbsp;million and the Company recorded goodwill of
$5.4&nbsp;million. The Company has consolidated Hansen&#146;s
results of operations since the acquisition date.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Comstock Net Services, Inc.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On July&nbsp;1, 2002 the Company
acquired Comstock Net Services, Inc. (&#147;Comstock&#148;), a
technology provider to real estate professionals, in exchange
for $1.8&nbsp;million in cash and 213,323&nbsp;shares of the
Company&#146;s stock. As a result of this acquisition the
Company recorded goodwill of $3.8&nbsp;million. The Company has
included Comstock&#146;s results of operations since
July&nbsp;1, 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Eastern Financial Systems, Inc.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;29, 2002 the Company
acquired all of the common stock of Eastern Financial Systems,
Inc. (&#147;Eastern&#148;), an industry leading mortgage loan
origination software provider in exchange for cash and stock.
Eastern&#146;s results of operations have been included in the
Company&#146;s Consolidated Financial Statements since the
acquisition date. The acquisition is expected to move the
Company a step closer to offering more complete data exchange
and technical integration between the sales, mortgage lending
and settlement service process of a real estate transaction.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The total purchase price consisted of
approximately $36.7&nbsp;million in cash (including transaction
costs) and 880,726&nbsp;shares of the Company&#146;s common
stock with a value of approximately $16.8&nbsp;million, based
upon the average closing price of $19.08 per share over a
five-day period using two days before and two days after the
measurement date.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">51
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

assigned to the customer relationship acquired and has a useful
life of seven&nbsp;years. The goodwill of $40.2&nbsp;million is
expected to be deductible for tax purposes.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">HomeServices of America.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">In December 2002, the Company
completed a strategic, multi-year outsourcing and software
application services agreement with HomeServices of America
(&#147;HomeServices&#148;), a residential real estate company
and a Berkshire Hathaway affiliate. It acquired the TRIO&#174;
software and certain other assets from HomeServices for a
purchase price of $2.0&nbsp;million in cash, which is payable
50% upon closing and 50% upon attainment of certain requirements
under the agreement. The Company recorded goodwill of
approximately $0.4&nbsp;million in connection with this
acquisition.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Environmental Risk Management Solutions.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On March&nbsp;25, 2002, the Company
sold its Environmental Risk Management Solutions business for
$15.5&nbsp;million in cash, resulting in a gain of
$0.3&nbsp;million. Proceeds from the sale were used to repay the
$12.6&nbsp;million balance then outstanding under the
Company&#146;s revolving credit agreement with Fidelity. The
remaining proceeds of $2.9&nbsp;million were added to general
working capital.
</FONT>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Discontinued
Operations</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In December 2001, MGEN adopted a plan to
discontinue the operations of its wholly-owned subsidiary,
LDExchange, which was engaged in the wholesale international
long distance business. MGEN recorded a charge of
$5.3&nbsp;million ($3.4&nbsp;million, net of taxes) for the
disposal of LDExchange. The charge consisted primarily of the
write-off of discontinued assets, goodwill and the accrual for
costs associated with facility shutdown and severance.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The accompanying Consolidated Financial
Statements reflect the results of operations of LDExchange
reported as discontinued operations for all periods presented.
Net assets (liabilities)&nbsp;of discontinued operations and the
loss from discontinued operations consist of the following (in
thousands):
</FONT>

amortization expense, which is no longer recorded under the
provision of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 (in thousands, except per share

<TR>
    <TD width="6%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="93%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">(1)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">MGEN, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company
    provides supporting services for SIMON and TEAM, real estate
    settlement software solutions used by Fidelity and its
    affiliates. In addition, the Company has been developing for
    Fidelity a new enterprise software solution, Net Global
    Solutions (&#147;NGS&#148;), which will eventually replace SIMON
    and TEAM. In connection with the Company&#146;s acquisition of
    MGEN on July&nbsp;9, 2002, the maintenance and services contract
    with Fidelity associated with supporting SIMON, TEAM, and NGS,
    as well as the NGS deployment contract were valued at
    approximately $19.6&nbsp;million, based on an independent
    valuation study. As the acquisition of the minority interest in
    MGEN was accounted for under the purchase accounting method, the
    Company recorded an intangible asset of $9.5&nbsp;million,
    representing the minority interest (48.8%) portion of the fair
    value of the contracts. The estimated useful lives of SIMON and
    TEAM maintenance contract, NGS deployment contract and NGS
    maintenance contract are 30&nbsp;months, 33&nbsp;months and
    20&nbsp;years, respectively.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

non-cancelable operating leases. The facility leases require the
payment of taxes, maintenance, utilities and insurance.

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Rent expense incurred under operating leases
during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000 was
$9.4&nbsp;million, $6.2&nbsp;million and $3.2&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2002, the Company entered into a purchase
commitment for telecommunication services totaling
$20.0&nbsp;million, extending through 2006, in connection with
services to be provided to Fidelity. The Company also entered
into an agreement to purchase a minimum of $7.0&nbsp;million of
computer equipment prior to December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In October 2001, the Company entered into a
strategic alliance agreement with Lexis-Nexis to acquire a 50%
ownership interest in their national real estate database. The
terms of the agreement require the Company to make annual
payments through October 2005 to complete the transaction. The
estimated payments to be made in the next three years are
$0.9&nbsp;million, $1.2&nbsp;million and $1.5&nbsp;million,
respectively. These payments may be accelerated at the
Company&#146;s option.
</FONT>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the $75.0&nbsp;million secured bank credit
facility as described in Note 11, the Company is required to pay
an annual commitment fee based on the usage of the line of
credit.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In the ordinary course of business, the Company
is involved in various pending and threatened litigation matters
related to its operations. Management believes that no actions,
other than those listed below, depart from customary litigation
incidental to the business of the Company and that the
resolution of all such litigation will not have a material
adverse effect on the Company&#146;s liquidity, financial
condition and results of operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">A class action lawsuit was filed against the
Company in Los Angeles County Superior Court on January&nbsp;3,
2000 alleging violations of state law and the
U.S.&nbsp;Telephone Consumer Protection Act (the TCPA) for
unsolicited advertising by facsimile. ACS&nbsp;Systems, Inc
(which merged with and into Micro General Corporation, effective
January&nbsp;1, 2001) contracted with Datamart to advertise its
services by fax. Plaintiff alleges the facsimiles did not
contain the proper notice to the recipients to notify the sender
to discontinue the advertising as required by the TCPA.
Plaintiff alleges that the damages to the class are
$7.0&nbsp;million if the violations of the statute were
unintentional and $21.0&nbsp;million if the violations of the
statute were intentional. In March 2002, the court granted
judgment on the Company&#146;s summary judgment motion. The
plaintiffs have appealed and the Company has cross-appealed. The
issues that will be determinative of the outcome of this
litigation are issues of &#147;first impression&#148;. It is not
possible to predict with any certainty how the court will rule
on appeal. While the Company intends to continue to vigorously
defend the case, there is no assurance that the eventual outcome
of the case will not have a material adverse effect on the
Company&#146;s business, financial position and operating
results.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The three actions related to flood certifications
discussed below have been filed against the Company by insurers
alleging that they incurred losses based upon inaccurate flood
certifications. These actions were filed against various
subsidiaries and the allegations related to National Research
Center (&#147;NRC&#148;), which was acquired as part of the
Vista transaction.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On May&nbsp;29, 2002 Travelers Indemnity filed a
complaint against NRC Insurance Services, Inc. in the
U.S.&nbsp;District Court, Eastern District of Missouri alleging
that NRC provided an erroneous flood certification when
Travelers underwrote a commercial location. Travelers Indemnity
seeks approximately $4.0&nbsp;million plus expenses in damages.
An amended complaint was filed on January&nbsp;15, 2003 adding
the Company and Vista Environmental Information, Inc., as
additional defendants. NRC and the other subsidiary defendants
filed their answer to the complaint on January&nbsp;31, 2003.
While the Company intends to continue to vigorously defend the
case, there is no assurance that the eventual outcome of the
case will not have a material adverse effect on the
Company&#146;s business, financial position and operating
results.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On May&nbsp;10, 2001, Pennsylvania Manufacturers
Association Indemnity Company, d/b/a PMA&nbsp;Group
(&#147;PMA&#148;)&nbsp;filed a complaint in the
U.S.&nbsp;District Court of New Jersey alleging that NRC
incorrectly issued a standard flood determination. PMA seeks
damages in the amount of $1.4&nbsp;million, representing the
amount paid to its insured, Brandywine Senior Care, Inc.
(&#147;Brandywine&#148;) which seeks an additional amount in
excess of $2.3&nbsp;million from PMA for alleged business income
loss. The obligation to pay business income loss is disputed by
PMA and is the subject of a Pennsylvania state court suit. If
PMA issues payment for business income loss, it will be added to
its claim for damages against NRC. The suit against NRC is
stayed pending resolution of the state court litigation between
PMA and Brandywine. While the Company intends to continue to
vigorously defend the case, there is no assurance that the
eventual outcome of the case will not have a material adverse
effect on the Company&#146;s business, financial position and
operating results.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On November&nbsp;6, 2002, St. Paul
Fire&nbsp;&#38; Marine filed a complaint against the Company in
the U.S.&nbsp;District Court, Eastern District of Missouri
alleging that NRC incorrectly issued a standard flood
determination, when St.&nbsp;Paul underwrote a commercial
location. Plaintiff seeks approximately $12.0&nbsp;million in
damages. There has been no response to the suit because the
complaint has not been served on NRC. While the Company intends
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Secured Bank Credit Facility.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On December&nbsp;20, 2002, the Company
and a group of banks entered into a credit facility agreement.
This credit facility, comprised of a revolving credit facility
and a standby letter of credit facility, provides for an
aggregate maximum line of credit of $75.0&nbsp;million that
expires in December 2005, and is secured by the assets of the
Company. The maximum credit line can be increased to
$100.0&nbsp;million under certain circumstances. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2002, there were no amounts outstanding under
the facility.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under this secured credit facility, the Company
may elect loan arrangements as either a Base Rate Loan or a
LIBOR Rate Loan. The Base Rate Loan bears an interest rate of
the greater of (a)&nbsp;the Prime Rate and (b)&nbsp;the Federal
Fund Rate plus 0.5%, plus an applicable margin of 0.25% to 0.75%
depending upon the Company&#146;s leverage ratio. Interest on
the Base Rate Loan is payable in arrears on the last business
day of each calendar quarter commencing March&nbsp;31, 2003. The
LIBOR Rate Loan&#146;s interest rate is LIBOR plus an applicable
margin of 1.50% to 2.00% depending upon the Company&#146;s
leverage ratio, and the Company may elect an interest period of
1, 2, 3 or 6&nbsp;months. Interest on the LIBOR Rate Loan is
payable on the last day of the interest period elected, and if
the interest period is over 3&nbsp;months, at the end of each
3&nbsp;months interval during such interest period. The Company
is also required to pay a non-refundable commitment fee at a
rate ranging from 0.375% to 0.625% per annum based on the usage
of the credit facility.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The credit agreement imposes certain affirmative
and negative covenants on the Company relating to current debt
ratings, certain financial ratios related to liquidity, net
worth, investments, acquisitions and restricted payments, and
certain dividend restrictions. The Company is in compliance with
all of its debt covenants as of December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Revolving Credit Facility with Parent.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On September&nbsp;24, 2001, the
Company entered into a revolving credit agreement with Fidelity.
The credit agreement provides for a maximum credit line of
$25&nbsp;million that expires and is due in September 2006. The
credit facility bears interest at a rate of Prime plus 2.0%.
Amounts borrowed under the credit facility were used to replace
the existing obligations to Fidelity related to the merger. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2001, $18.7&nbsp;million was outstanding
under the credit facility. In March 2002, the Company repaid the
amounts borrowed under this facility using the proceeds from the
sale of its Environmental Risk Management Solutions business. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2002, there were no amounts
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">58
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
AND SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">outstanding under this facility. In addition, as
a result of the $75.0&nbsp;million secured bank credit agreement
entered in December 2002 as described above, this parent
facility became subordinated.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Hansen Note.</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> In
connection with the acquisition of the 55% interest in Hansen on
May&nbsp;28, 2002, the Company issued a convertible note in the
amount of $4.1&nbsp;million. The note bears an interest rate of
4.5% per annum, matures in May 2005 and was convertible at any
time into shares of the Company&#146;s common stock at $28.00
per share. The conversion feature was subsequently eliminated by
mutual consent of the parties to the note.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Mortgage Loan. </FONT></I><FONT size="2">The
Company assumed a mortgage note in connection with the
acquisition of Eastern. This mortgage note was secured by a
building and certain assets of Eastern, bearing an interest rate
of 7.5% per annum, with monthly installment of $11,000 until
2007 and no prepayment penalty. The loan was paid in full in
February 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Convertible Note with Parent.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">In 1999, MGEN entered into a
$5.3&nbsp;million five-year convertible note with Fidelity. This
note bears an interest rate of 10% per annum, payable quarterly
and was due December&nbsp;14, 2004. On July&nbsp;24, 2002,
Fidelity exercised its option to convert this $5.3&nbsp;million
convertible note into 403,120 shares of FNIS common stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Equipment Financing Arrangements.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">During 2001 and 2000, one of our
subsidiaries entered into a series of notes for equipment
financing arrangements with interest rates ranging from 5.67% to
11.30% and terms ranging from one to three years. These notes
are secured by an agreement which assigns the respective revenue
streams payable by Fidelity to the note holders in the event of
a default by this subsidiary on the respective notes.
</FONT>

<P align="left">

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">60
